text:
Good morning. My name is Andy Zelleke. And on behalf of
my HBS colleagues

I want to warmly
welcome all of you to Perspectives on
the COVID-19 Pandemic, Assessing the Challenge
and Making a Difference.

We're so delighted that
our audience today includes MBA and doctoral students,
staff and faculty, alumni tuning

in from all over the world,
and also, the most recent group of new admits to
our MBA program--

folks who haven't
yet matriculated, but we sincerely hope to be
joining us as RCs this fall.

Welcome to all. We hope that at this
difficult time all of you, and your families,
and loved ones are staying healthy and
navigating this situation well,

and even finding
new ways to thrive. A few words about the
genesis of this day.

Six weeks ago, we made
the painful decision to cancel this year's Field
Global Immersion, or FGI.

Since 2011, FGI has been a
key part of the first year curriculum, an opportunity
for our first-year students

to work with local companies
on four continents. Our RCs have been
excitedly looking forward
to their May 2020 immersions. COVID-19 derailed those plans.

Of course, it's changed
everybody's plans. With COVID-19 top-of-mind
on our campus,

we decided to put together
today's program with our RCs foremost in mind.

And with two primary
goals for content, we wanted to help our
students better understand

the COVID-19 challenge in
its various dimensions. And with our school's
mission always in mind,

we wanted our students and
the rest of our community to hear from and be
inspired by business leaders

making a significant
difference in this fight. And so we're thrilled to have
this spectacular lineup today.

Our first and final sessions are
with prominent business leaders who saw, in crisis, not
just the opportunity,

but the duty for business
to go above and beyond in creating value. Value not focused solely on
shareholders, but especially

in this emergency,
on the societies in which business is embedded.

We open with Ken Chenault,
known to all of you as one of America's
most celebrated CEOs

of his generation. And we close with
Revathi Advaithi, CEO of global manufacturing
heavyweight, Flex.

Business is periodically called
on by academics, politicians, sometimes by prominent
business people,

to elevate its game
as corporate citizen. These calls don't always
have tangible impact.

Something different, though,
seems to be happening now. Businesses are stepping
out of their usual lanes

to help out in
very tangible ways in the fight against COVID-19. And Ken and Revathi have
prominent roles in this.

In Between Ken's and
Revathi's sessions, we'll hear from four of Harvard
University's brightest lights--

Ashish Jha, a leading authority
on public health and policy interventions,
Juliette Kayyem, who

as a senior federal and state
Homeland Security official, helped keep us safe from threats
from terrorism to pandemics.

And then, two of our
most renowned economists with expertise on financial
crises and on globalization--

Carmen Reinhart and Dani Rodrik. These four scholars and
public intellectuals

will help all of us interpret
the COVID-19 challenge to health, to jobs, to
our national economies,

to globalization,
to the way we live, and help us think about
what may lie ahead,

and what should lie ahead. With our guests having
so much on their plates these days, we're especially
grateful that they

made the time to be with us
today, and grateful as well to our HBS colleagues-- experts in their own rights--

who stepped forward to
moderate these conversations. Three quick admin points
and then we'll go.

We're recording this
program, and it'll be made available to
you in a few days.

So if seven hours of Zoom
webinar in one sitting is too much for you, we get it.

But please do come
back to the recording and watch all the sessions. Second, our love extends to
every member of our community,

including everyone
attending today. But having designed this program
specifically for the RCs,

we'll respectfully ask
that non-RCs please refrain from raising your hand
on Zoom during the Q&A

with our speakers. Let's all agree to leave that
Q&A opportunity to our RCs.

We appreciate your
understanding on that. Last point, if you
have tech difficulty,

please log out and
then log back in. That should cure the problem. All right, our keynote
session featuring Ken Chenault

and dialogue with Karen Mills
begins promptly at 9:15, but we're going to start
half a minute early.
So back to you in 10 seconds.

Three seconds, that is. Welcome to our first session,
the business community's opportunity to step up
collectively featuring

Ken Chenault, Chairman
of General Catalyst and formerly Chairman and
CEO of American Express.

Our moderator is HBS
Professor, Karen Mills, who formerly headed the US
Small Business Administration.
Over to you, Karen.

Organizers at HBS, this is
actually an incredible lineup. So good morning HBS students.

Good morning, section
I. I miss you. But I'll see you next week.

Today, we have
the great pleasure of having Ken Chenault with us. Ken is not an HBS grad.

He is a Harvard Law School grad
and a Bowdoin College grad, but he has two sons
who have come to HBS.

One is right now with us at HBS. So as an HBS parent and also
as a Harvard Corporation member

he is very loyal and very
involved in the school. So welcome, Ken.

And I'm going to start out
with a story about when I first

got to know you and
your leadership. More than 10 years ago, when I
was running the Small Business

Administration, you were
running American Express. And you developed a--

really a movement that was
called Small Business Saturday. And you came to us
after about a year

when it had gained a
little bit of momentum. You said, you know what? We want to let this thing go
out of the umbrella of American

Express and have it be
for all small businesses. We want to not make sure that
everybody has to an Amex card

to make their purchase. We want to have it belong
to small businesses, will you help us?

And we got together. And now, of the very few small
business brands out there,

Small Business Saturday
has a life of its own. I was in the UK, and they
have Small Business Saturday

even though they don't
have Thanksgiving. So I got to know your style,
which I would characterize as,

do the right thing and
the rewards will follow. So here we are with COVID-19.

Can you talk about
your leadership style in this moment, and how you
see doing the right thing

manifesting itself today? Thanks, Karen. Well, first of all,
it's great to be here.

And it's always terrific to
be with you, and to be at HBS.

And I do want to give
a shout out to my son, Kevin who's in
section C. But really,

everyone at Harvard
Business School, connected with Harvard
Business School.

This is really a horrific
time that we're in.

And to just talk a little bit
about Small Business Saturday,

and I know we'll
get into COVID-19. The reality for me of my
leadership philosophy,

I think it starts with your
personal values and beliefs. And as you know, Karen, I'm a
child of the '60s and the '70s,

having gone through the Civil
Rights Movement, the Vietnam era. And I was not someone
who had as my aspiration

growing up that I would be
CEO of a Fortune 100 company.

In fact, I had zero
interest in business. I wanted to save the world.

And that was my focus. But I think what I've carried
is this mission that I

want to make a meaningful
difference in people's lives. I do believe that
business companies have

a social and moral obligation. And so with respect to
Small Business Saturday,

as you know, the focus
was, how do we dramatically

improve small business? And when we thought
about it and came to you,

what became clear to me is
we had to put the singular

interests of American Express-- we had to put that
on the back burner

and really say, what would it
take to dramatically change small business?

And what we wanted to do was to
highlight, not against big box

retailers, but, in fact,
to say small businesses are core to our economy.

We need to have local
communities support small business.

And so we decided-- and it was frankly controversial
inside the company-- that we would allow any
type of payment product--

cash, checks-- as much
as I hate to say it-- MasterCard and Visa. They could use any
type of product

as long as they
supported small business. And that, I think,
had a major impact

and demonstrated to me the
collective power of business bringing about real change.

We're going to talk
about what you're doing now in big business.

But I want to turn to
government for a second. I happen to know that you are
offered by President Obama

any number of major
cabinet roles. And you said no to all of them.

But at this moment, let's
imagine that you had said yes, or that you were in charge.

President Obama would stick
us in the cabinet room, and he'd assign jobs. And commerce would
get the supply chain.

So let's imagine that you are
in charge of America's supply chain and all of its businesses.

What do you think
governments should be doing to get
some of the things

that we need in
this country moving? And what have you been
doing outside of government

in recognition of the
fact that the supply chain needed some help? Well, I think,
first of all, what's

very important in
any crisis is, one,

you have to demonstrate
a level of decisiveness.

And for me, my
leadership mantra is the role of a leader is to
define reality and give hope.

We live in incredibly
uncertain times. But part of what the
leadership needs to do

is in fact to
demonstrate to people that they understand some
of the levers that could

help bring about improvement. And so I think one of roles,
whether it's the president,

whether it's a governor,
whether it's a mayor, is you need to coalesce
different organizations

and people against
some key actions. So if we go to the
supply chain, I

think what's very, very
important there is one, we've got to have a framework
to manage supply and demand.

How do we set priorities? And this is not just
a technical issue. This is a hope issue
for the populace.

That if people understood
what's the reality on supply?

Here are the steps we're
taking to, in fact, improve the supply,
here the demand issues

that we're facing, and we're
actually going to prioritize.

That's important from
a efficiency standpoint to get the right products and
services to the right people,

but it also gives people
hope that, in fact, someone is analyzing these
issues and taking--

You took this on, Ken. And tell us what you did
with ventilator supply.

Sure. So let me, one, back up,
because I believe, obviously, in a time of crisis--

and I'm a firm
believer in this-- no matter what your level,
no matter what your role,

no matter whether you are
officially sanctioned or not, everyone can take
a leadership role.

And so, literally, I think
it was around 18 days ago, we put together a group--

and when I say we, my
co-founder is a person by the name of
Rachel Carlson, who's

the founder of a company called
Guild Education that is focused on workforce education.

And we were talking about the
need for the business community to, in fact, take a
collective response,

but also from a prioritization
standpoint, what were areas

that we thought a
fast, agile group could

make a real difference? And so we picked three areas. And we took a startup
mentality to this.

We said what we want
to be is we want to be catalysts to
bring about change.

Another criteria was,
let's keep the recognition level of ourselves
very low, because we

want to really be supportive
and drive change, but not be

the individuals out front. And what we did
was, we said there

are three areas we think
we could have an impact. One was to increase the
supply and distribution

of ventilators. Second was PPE, and third
was testing and diagnostics.

So what we did was I
made a call to Mary Barra and suggested that she think
about repurposing her plant.

Mary is an unbelievable
patriot, and I think a real hero in this.

She immediately said, I
think that's a good idea.

In two hours, we connected her
to a ventilator manufacturer. And literally in
48 hours Mary said,

I think I'm going to do this. We then got some other
manufacturers involved--

both ventilator
manufacturers and companies that would repurpose plants-- and we did the same
thing with PPE.

And what we saw was there was
a need, in fact, to catalyze people against an
objective, there

was a need to connect people. But once we were able
to connect people,

we played a supportive role, and
we let people like Mary lead,

which she's done a
terrific job in doing. So this is happening all
across a set of efforts

where you've galvanized
a bunch of CEOs to move together and
solve critical problems.

What do you think, today, as you
look at the business roundtable and other leadership,
what do you

wish they were doing more of? Where do you think maybe they
need another boost, perhaps,

to help their employees, to
do some other things that are pressing in the crisis?

So I would say a
few things, Karen. One is, obviously, this
crisis is unprecedented.

Having navigated
through 9/11, navigated

through the financial
crisis, there is, frankly not a comparison.

I really think this is 9/11,
plus the financial crisis,

a multiple of two or three. So it's incredible. So the individual companies are
facing tremendous challenges.

I think I see a number
of CEOs stepping up. But what I would
like to see even more

was this collective
focus against priorities. I'd like to see even more
partnerships being developed,

because I'm a
believer in business and in crises is when you're
facing unprecedented times,

positively or in a negative
way, what you have to do is you have to transform.

And so the way we
operate as companies, we can't operate the same
way as we did pre-crisis.

We have to fundamentally change. So I'd like to see more
innovation around partnerships

on the part of corporations. And I think what we also are
starting to see even more of is

corporations recognizing-- and
I see some positive signs-- that they've got to make
some very important changes

for our society overall. Because what COVID-19 has
put in even more stark relief

are the disparities that
exist in our society.

Yeah, say some more about that. If you had to hope for some
lessons from corporate America

for the future about these
disparities, what would you do-- if you were sort of
in charge and could

have a wish, that all
of corporate America would change a certain aspect
of the way they do business,

and make an impact on
this issue that we're facing on inequality,
what might you

suggest that
corporate America do? I think, one, very
clearly, there

needs to be a very strong focus
on education and training.

So education at an early stage. So in the communities
where companies

are, and around the world,
being focused on education

is very, very important. Workforce training is
absolutely essential.

I am very passionate
about it because I think we have not
just an obligation,

but I think it's a tremendous
opportunity for companies to focus on training
and education.

So that would be a very,
very strong priority. I think, secondly,
is I think companies
can focus on their own people.

More of, what are
the needs of people that are at the lower end of the
income and salary at a company?

What are they doing
to retrain them? What are they doing from
a health care standpoint?

So I think that
there are things that need to be done at the company
that will very much address

some of these issues. And then I think there
are broader societal needs

that companies need to address. And part of that
is going to happen by private/public partnerships.

It's also going to happen by
companies partnering together. And one of the things that--

I don't want to champion
what you and I did, Karen-- but I do think it was
novel to have a program that,

in fact, has gone through
changes in small business,

but it wasn't an issue of a
typical government company

program. I think it was a very
innovative partnership. So I think that those
are things companies

need to be more involved in. Now, I want to turn to big
tech and entrepreneurs.

Because you left
American Express, and you had a lot of job opportunities.

And what did you do? You became the chairman
of General Catalyst and you own all kinds of
entrepreneurial companies.

You went on the board of a bunch
of the most famous big tech companies and are very
active in Silicon Valley.

So what should Silicon
Valley be doing today, and maybe in the future,
to use their technology
to help us out of this crisis? Should we be tracking people?

How do we think about
technology and privacy? Where is the role of big tech?

So I think big tech is
an incredible enabler.

But I think also needs
to increasingly recognize

the responsibility that
it has to lead the change

and to deal with the
implications of people being left out.

So big tech needs to be far
more inclusive than it has been. And one of the
points that I always

make when I talk to
big tech or little tech is, if you want to
disrupt the world,

then the question is, what are
you doing to change the world? And if you are simply
accepting the status quo,

that is not being disruptive
in all aspects of your life.

And you need to, in
fact, be disruptive, you need to bring about change,
but you have a responsibility

to advance society. One of the reasons why I
decided to be very involved

in technology is one,
I love technology. But second, what I believe
is that technology is just

a great enabler. And technology needs not just
to bring about innovation,

but they need to bring
about real change that is going to dramatically--

dramatically-- improve people's
station in our society.

I want to switch gears for-- cover something else,
which is that you

are a member of the
Harvard Corporation-- a terrific colleague
there-- but you are also the head of the
Finance Committee for Harvard

for the corporation. Can you take us under
the curtain a little bit and tell us how this
Harvard position to faces

this great uncertainty? What is Harvard doing
to come through this?

And how do you feel about
its position, financially?

So look, I think
every institution,

every company is certainly
dealing with, I would say,

And I think Harvard
is in that situation. And when you're in a crisis-- and I would start here--

it really goes to understanding,
what do you stand for?
What do you believe? What's the mission? What are your objectives?

So one, I would say is,
I think Harvard is very clear about what it stands for.

I think, very importantly, I
think the overarching need that

has to be addressed is the
safety and health of everyone involved in Harvard--

with Harvard. But I think that what I
have been very encouraged

and heartened by is both the
approach that Harvard is taking

and the leadership of Harvard. And I'm not saying
this because I'm just a member of the
Harvard Corporation.

That's just not
the way I operate. I think we're incredibly
fortunate to have Larry Bacow.

I think he's a person who
has incredibly strong values.

He is, indeed, an empathetic
decisive leader, which is what you need in a crisis.

He will communicate
transparently what reality is.

But I think he's
also someone who will communicate and demonstrate
tangible reasons to be hopeful.

And so here are
some of the reasons, despite this unprecedented
crisis, why I'm hopeful.

I think we've got probably the
most experienced capable team

of any university in the world. Again, Larry has
gone through crises,

he has those
personal attributes. Alan Garber. Alan Garber is someone who--

he understands
infectious diseases.

He is a economist,
he is a doctor,

he has been very focused
on these set of issues. Katie Lapp, the Chief
Administrative Officer.

Katie could run a company and
she is absolutely incredible. So this team has
developed a game plan.

And as you know, Karen,
one of the things that was started at the business school-- I want to give a
shout out to Nitin

and Angela Crispi is, the
business school, under Nitin's

leadership developed
a recession playbook that we have been focused on,
Harvard, for several years.

And so while this-- no one could plan for
this type of crisis,

we've been able to
build on this playbook. And I feel very good
about the scenarios

that we are working through. What I would also say
that-- one of things I believe in a crisis you have
to set some key objectives.

And one of the areas that
we have set objectives

so we can manage
Harvard in a good way is, one, very practically
is stay liquid.

That's an objective. From a financial standpoint,
you want to stay liquid. When American Express was going
through the financial crisis,

that was my first objective. Stay liquid. Second was and is,
manage expenses

to match declining
revenues, but do it with setting
strategic priorities.

So that's the second
important objective. And the third-- and this
gets to the hope part--

we may need to make to
academic offerings-- efficiency changes-- but
to look for opportunities.

And so what I would emphasize
is that Harvard will--

has already taken
some painful actions. Will have to probably take more.

But I really do think that
everyone connected with Harvard

should have confidence
in our leadership, and confidence that
on a relative basis

Harvard is positioned well. But the reality is that painful
actions will have to be taken.

But what I believe is
that we have a strategy,

we have the criteria,
we have the values. And I would just emphasize
that, given the incredibly

challenging times
we're in, we're very fortunate to
have the leadership

that we have at Harvard. Yeah. I want to second that. And Ken, I want to thank
you for the leadership.

And I know you've mentioned,
also, Tom Hollister who is the head VP of finance.

Tom is absolutely--
he is someone, by the way, again, who is
incredibly focused on doing

what's right for Harvard. And he's really driven
by the values of Harvard.

And he's someone
who has been battle tested, even though no one
has faced a battle like we're

facing now. No. This is a tremendous battle. And I will say that
Harvard is thinking

about its whole community. I focus a lot on the
small business piece, but I know that you brought
up in all kinds of companies,

but including Harvard,
paying small businesses soon. Because as you
mentioned, staying liquid

is a priority now. As I tell my students,
when you run out of cash, when you run out of
money, you're dead.

So-- That is really,
really important. But Karen, that was your idea.

And I think it was
a terrific idea to pay people forward, so
that if a small business has

rendered a product or service,
rather than pay them in 30, 45 days, pay them immediately.

And you've been such a champion
for small business that--

and I will just say, Karen and
I are still working together,

trying to figure out ways
to help small business as we go through COVID-19.

Yes. And thank you for that. So Andy, I think we probably
have a lot of RC students

who want to ask Ken a question. And Ken, I'll come back at the
end for one last one of mine.

Mm-hmm. Very good, Karen. If you've got a question
and you're an RC,

please click on the raise hand
icon, bottom of your toolbar,
and we'll set you up. There you go. Kaia?

Can you hear me? There we go. Yeah. I'm not an RC, but I
did have a question,

so I seized the opportunity,
if you'll humor me. Of course, go ahead. My question was with
reference to what

you're talking about, getting
the consortium of businesses to work together, the discussion
about how partnership is really

what's the force that
can really amplify what you guys can do right now.

I'm curious what
you think is needed to bridge the gap in the
large corporate world

to build those partnerships? There's obviously early
momentum and calling

GM worked very well. But what do you think
gets us from A to Z there, because there's
obviously so much left to do?

I think a focus on
some common objectives. Let's look at a few areas.
One is return to work.

A single company cannot decide
on its own to return to work.

So there are partnerships being
created amongst companies,

figuring out what
are the steps that need to be taken from a
return-to-work standpoint.

There are conversations
going on right now between governors, and mayors,
and businesses on what to do.

I think the recently
announced partnership with Google and Apple on
tracing is an example.

And so what I would
emphasize is that there are different industry
groups that are involved

in bringing companies together. But I think what's
also happening

is companies on their
own are coming together against common objectives.

And frankly, I think the
government, whether it's at the local level,
state, or federal,

can be both a convener and
a facilitator of building

relationships in
the private sector. So I think there are
a variety of pathways

to drive partnerships. And what's important
is, in any crisis,

what you do see can it can
be an accelerant for changes

in positive behavior. And what I will tell you
that I've seen in my 18 days

that I've been very
directly involved is a real acceleration
and a willingness

on the part of a range
of companies to partner. Question from Sunny
Huang, please.

Can you hear me? Yes, go ahead. So I was wondering,
as entrepreneurs

at HBS, what kind
of lasting changes do you see extend beyond
this COVID-19 impact

that when we think about
building businesses, we can help meet these needs,
and solve these problems,

and build businesses
that have lasting impact? So I think what's very
important for me is
the mission for entrepreneurs--

the mission statement,
for example, for General Catalyst
is, we want to invest

in powerful positive
change that endures for our society and
our entrepreneurs.

And we are very focused. And I believe this
strongly is, one

of things I ask
entrepreneurs and founders is, are you building a
company that will endure,

and are you building a company
that, in fact, is going to drive a social purpose, as
well as be a terrific business?

And it's not an either/or. Because if we're really
focused on doing what's

best in the long-term,
then, in fact, we need a healthy
and vibrant society.

And so it's important to me
that our entrepreneurs not just

focus on, what's a
way for me simply to create a product
that is going

to be very attractive
to a range of people, but is it going to be a
product that will last?

Will it be a product
that will endure? Will it be a product that
will have a positive impact
on our society? So I think it's a choice-- and an individual choice.

We live in an
open, free society. So no one is going to
force you to do that.

But the reality is that if
you are starting a business, my view is, start a business
that means something.

Start a business going to
have an impact on the broader society, and build that
in from the beginning.

Don't say, well, I need to, in
fact, first achieve success, and then I'm going to do some
good things in the world.

That's not the way I think
you operate a company.

Let's take one from
Nick Rosenbaum, please.

[INTERPOSING VOICES] Thank you, for sharing all
those wonderful lessons from this crisis.

My question is actually to
jump off what you just said, which is, when you're thinking
about building businesses,

how to make them for the
long-term and for impact. So I think in a crisis we see
the best come out of people

and we see amazing
collective action. But how do we keep
that collective action and make sure that
businesses are still

accountable to society
after the crisis is done? So I think what's
very important,

Nick, is you've got to go
back to how you construct
the mission of your company. Why are you doing this?

I think you've got to
answer that question. What are the cultural,
and what are the values,

and what are the attributes
that you want your company to stand for?

So my view is, just as
you should do personally, of saying, what do I believe?

What do I stand for? What are my values? You need to do the same
thing for your company.

Because a culture
of a company is

what really allows
that company to endure. You obviously need
a terrific strategy,

you need great products,
you need great services, you need very strong economics.

But if you want to build
a company that endures, you have to have an
incredibly strong culture.

And that culture needs
to operate in good times

and challenging times. And so focus on what you want
the company to stand for.

And make sure that as you are
implementing your strategies,

building your
organization, you're reinforcing in very tangible
ways the values of the company.

Brendan Lind, let's
try you again.

Hey. My question is, as students,
what should we be doing,

and what do you think we can
do to use this time where we have more free time, we have--

there's a bunch of
us-- what can we do to play a role and
support in a time of crisis?

And yeah, how would you
recommend we get involved and actually make a difference?

So I think what
I would recommend

is, there are organizations both
directly involved in the crisis

at the local level
or national level that I would encourage
